results.title: Fiber Is Good for You. Now Scientists May Know Why.
results.abstract: A series of unusual experiments in mice finds that dietary fiber fine-tunes the immune system and may help prevent chronic inflammation.

results.title: Beach Crawling Doesn’t Tire Out Baby Sea Turtles
results.abstract: When hatchling turtles tackled a treadmill, their stop-and-go style of crawling kept them fresh enough for a big swim to the Gulf Stream.

multimedia.caption: Artificial lighting disorients sea turtle hatchlings after they emerge from their nests. But despite their confusion on the beach, a study finds, the baby turtles maintain enough energy to swim to safety.

Artificial lighting disorients sea turtle hatchlings after they emerge from their nests. But despite their confusion on the beach, a study finds, the baby turtles maintain enough energy to swim to safety.

results.title: U.F.O.s: Is This All There Is?
results.abstract: Astronomers have their noses pressed against the windows of the unknown, wanting to believe in life elsewhere just like many outer space enthusiasts.

multimedia.caption: A U.F.O. in New Mexico in 1957. For astronomers, the biggest problem with alien visitation is not the occasional claim of mysterious light in the sky, but the fact that we’re not constantly overwhelmed with them.

A U.F.O. in New Mexico in 1957. For astronomers, the biggest problem with alien visitation is not the occasional claim of mysterious light in the sky, but the fact that we’re not constantly overwhelmed with them.

results.title: Scientists Are Designing Artisanal Proteins for Your Body
results.abstract: The human body makes tens of thousands of cellular proteins, each for a particular task. Now researchers have learned to create custom versions not found in nature.

results.title: In Winter, You Might Wish You Had This Rodent Superpower
results.abstract: Scientists discovered a quirk in the proteins of some squirrels and hamsters that helps them behave a bit like a coldblooded animal.

multimedia.caption: The Syrian hamster, too, can adjust its body temperature to withstand prolonged cold.
multimedia.copyright: Arterra/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images

results.title: Tesla the Car Is a Household Name. Long Ago, So Was Nikola Tesla.
results.abstract: The star of a man once renowned as the prototype of a genius inventor has faded. But his reputation is having a revival, and his creations still resonate.

multimedia.caption: The inventor Nikola Tesla around 1896. Tesla died a poor man in 1943 at age 86, but thanks to Elon Musk and his electric car company, “now he’s getting his due,” a biographer said.
The inventor Nikola Tesla around 1896. Tesla died a poor man in 1943 at age 86, but thanks to Elon Musk and his electric car company, “now he’s getting his due,” a biographer said.

results.title: Researchers Warn of a Spreading Fungus Deadly to Snakes
results.abstract: Bats and frogs and salamanders have all been hit hard by white nose syndrome and chytrid fungi. Now scientists are warning that snakes worldwide are at risk from a new fungal disease.

multimedia.caption: The timber rattlesnake, one of about two dozen species of snakes that are susceptible to infection with a deadly fungus. The fungus may decimate snake populations, scientists say.
The timber rattlesnake, one of about two dozen species of snakes that are susceptible to infection with a deadly fungus. The fungus may decimate snake populations, scientists say.

results.title: Fighting Climate Change, One Laundry Load at a Time
results.abstract: Experts in the study of fungi are playing a bigger role in improving laundry detergents and, by extension, leading efforts to cut energy use.

multimedia.caption: Two Novozymes employees, Sara Landvik, left, and Mikako Sasa, looking for mushrooms in Hareskoven Forest, near Copenhagen. The company studies enzymes that speed up chemical reactions or natural processes like decay.
multimedia.copyright: Carsten Snejbjerg for The New York Times

results.title: Rocket Launches and Trips to the Moon We’re Looking Forward to in 2018
results.abstract: The launch of a new rocket by Elon Musk’s SpaceX and moon landings by India, China and private companies could occur this year, but no one is sure when.

multimedia.caption: Contrails from the launch of SpaceX’s Falcon 9 rocket on Dec. 22, 2017 in Apple Valley, Calif.

results.title: How Does the Shape of a Head Affect the Brain?
results.abstract: Studies of head compression are inconclusive as to whether cranial shaping caused learning or behavior disorders.

results.title: New Slaughtering Rules Pit Dutch Religious Freedoms Against Animal Rights
results.abstract: The authorities say the rules are intended to make kosher and halal slaughtering more humane, but some Jews and Muslims say they feel singled out.

multimedia.caption: The Slagerij Marcus kosher butcher shop in Amsterdam. Jewish and Muslim groups have agreed to change ritual slaughter practices in the face of pressure from animal rights activists.
multimedia.copyright: Jasper Juinen for The New York Times

results.title: Trump Ends Terms of Remaining Members of H.I.V. and AIDS Council
results.abstract: The council’s executive director said the dismissals were common when a new administration takes office. Six members resigned in June in protest of President Trump.
results.byline: By MATT STEVENS and DANIEL VICTOR

multimedia.caption: The White House honored World AIDS Day this month. The remaining members of the Presidential Advisory Council on H.I.V. and AIDS were dismissed this week.
The White House honored World AIDS Day this month. The remaining members of the Presidential Advisory Council on H.I.V. and AIDS were dismissed this week.

results.title: Deaths in 2017: Among the Luminaries, Fighters With a Cause
results.abstract: Remembering Mary Tyler Moore, Chuck Berry, Jerry Lewis, Sam Shepard, Della Reese and many more, but also a remarkable roster of champions who pressed for change.

multimedia.caption: Norma McCorvey, right, with attorney Gloria Allred in California in 1989. Ms. McCorvey was the “Jane Doe” of Roe v. Wade, but eventually changed her mind about abortion rights. She died on Sept. 22.

results.title: Ben Barres, Neuroscientist and Equal-Opportunity Advocate, Dies at 63
results.abstract: Dr. Barres, who in 1997 transitioned from female to male, drew on his experiences as a woman to highlight the obstacles women in science face.

multimedia.caption: Dr. Ben Barres at Stanford University in 2006. “People are still arguing over whether there are cognitive differences between men and women,” he said. “If they exist, it’s not clear they are innate, and if they are innate, it’s not clear they are relevant.”
multimedia.copyright: Thor Swift for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Dr. Ben Barres at Stanford University in 2006. “People are still arguing over whether there are cognitive differences between men and women,” he said. “If they exist, it’s not clear they are innate, and if they are innate, it’s not clear they are relevant.”
multimedia.copyright: Thor Swift for The New York Times

results.title: U.S. to Roll Back Safety Rules Created After Deepwater Horizon Spill
results.abstract: The Interior Department said reversing the Obama-era regulations would reduce “unnecessary burdens” on the energy industry.
results.byline: By LISA FRIEDMAN and HIROKO TABUCHI

multimedia.caption: The Deepwater Horizon drilling platform after an explosion in April 2010.

results.title: It’s Cold Outside. Cue the Trump Global Warming Tweet.
results.abstract: With frigid temperatures in the East, President Trump cast doubt on the reality of climate change. But weather is not the same as climate.

multimedia.caption: After a snowfall this week in Erie, Pa. Parts of the East Coast are bracing for record-breaking New Year’s Eve temperatures.
After a snowfall this week in Erie, Pa. Parts of the East Coast are bracing for record-breaking New Year’s Eve temperatures.

results.title: E.P.A. Wanted Years to Study Lead Paint Rule. It Got 90 Days.
results.abstract: A federal panel told the agency to revise its standard for dangerous levels of lead in paint within a year.

results.title: F.D.A. Leaves Tainted Foods on Shelves Too Long, Report Finds
results.abstract: The agency has the authority to force recalls of contaminated foods but is not adequately ensuring timely compliance, an inspector general’s report concludes.

multimedia.caption: Scott Gottlieb, head of the F.D.A., said the agency has been working to be faster and better at implementing food recalls.
Scott Gottlieb, head of the F.D.A., said the agency has been working to be faster and better at implementing food recalls.

results.title: Jerold F. Lucey, Innovator in Premature Births, Dies at 91
results.abstract: Dr. Lucey helped introduce new treatments for fragile newborns and edited the journal Pediatrics for 35 years.

multimedia.caption: Dr. Jerold F. Lucey in 1997. “I don’t think there’s a pediatrician who doesn’t realize that some aspect of their career is because of a contribution that Jerry Lucey made,” a colleague said.
Dr. Jerold F. Lucey in 1997. “I don’t think there’s a pediatrician who doesn’t realize that some aspect of their career is because of a contribution that Jerry Lucey made,” a colleague said.

results.title: What We Mean When We Say Evidence-Based Medicine
results.abstract: People understand different things by this term, and the arguments don’t divide along predictable partisan lines, either.

multimedia.caption: The benefits of evidence-based medicine, when properly applied, are obvious. We can use evidence from treatments to help people make better choices.
The benefits of evidence-based medicine, when properly applied, are obvious. We can use evidence from treatments to help people make better choices.

results.title: ‘Nobody Thought It Would Come to This’: Drug Maker Teva Faces a Crisis
results.abstract: The move by Israel’s corporate version of a celebrity to lay off 14,000 workers was greeted with outrage and a nationwide strike.
results.byline: By DAVID SEGAL and ISABEL KERSHNER

multimedia.caption: Workers protesting outside a Teva factory in Jerusalem this month after the company said it would lay off 14,000 employees.
Workers protesting outside a Teva factory in Jerusalem this month after the company said it would lay off 14,000 employees.

results.title: Measles Deaths Fall to a Record Low Worldwide
results.abstract: Thanks to vaccines, the disease — which not long ago killed over 2 million children a year — now kills fewer than 100,000, the W.H.O. reported.

multimedia.caption: A child receiving measles vaccine in a refugee camp in Bangladesh last month. Annual deaths from measles have fallen below 100,000 worldwide, according to the World Health Organization.
A child receiving measles vaccine in a refugee camp in Bangladesh last month. Annual deaths from measles have fallen below 100,000 worldwide, according to the World Health Organization.

results.title: How It Works: The Large Mouth of the Largemouth Bass
results.abstract: The bones in the legendary maw of the largemouth bass function according to a well-known engineering model, scientists have found.

results.title: One Man’s Stand Against Junk Food as Diabetes Climbs Across India
results.abstract: India is “sitting on a volcano” of diabetes. A father’s effort to ban junk food sales in and near schools aims to change what children eat.

multimedia.caption: Street meals in New Delhi. Scientists have found that Indians are more likely to get diabetes as they gain weight than people from other regions.
multimedia.copyright: Atul Loke for The New York Times
